p: Although the use of RC extract for gastrointestinal problems seems to be related to its presumptive smooth muscle-relaxant effect, interestingly no in vitro or in vivo studies have been carried out so far to assess this bioactivity. However, in an in vitro study an aqueous extract of C. nobile was demonstrated to induce a vasorelaxant effect through the NO-cGMP pathway or possibly through a combination of Ca 2+ channel inhibition plus NO-modulating and phosphodiesterase inhibitory mechanisms. After the oral administration of RC aqueous extract, significant hypotensive effect was observed in an animal study on spontaneously hypertensive rats ( Zeggwagh et al., 2009), which may be related to the flavonoid content of the plant ( Jouad et al., 2001). The clinical efficacy of orally applied preparations has not been studied yet, only the effects of external application ( Schrader et al., 1997) and aromatherapeutic use ( Wilkinson et al., 1999) have been reported.
